lead_paragraph: WALKER--Barbara Martin, 92, unexpectedly March 25, her family with her. Born in Manhattan, raised in Riverdale and Newtown, CT, Barbara attended Putney School, Wellesley College, and Trinity Washington University. During WWII Barbara drove a truck for the Red Cross in New York City and in 1948 married Robert Gill Walker of Meadville, PA. Bob's work as Foreign Service Officer, U.S. Department of State led them to Rio de Janeiro, Buenos Aires and Santiago, Chile. They also lived in Chevy Chase and retired to Princeton and Hightstown, NJ. She served as Spouse of a Foreign Service Officer; History Teacher, Spingarn High School; Guidance Counselor, Washington International School, D.C. She was Representative to the United Nations for the International Schools Association, and cofounded the Committee on Teaching about the United Nations, a UN/NGO partnership. She and Bob were lifelong supporters of the World Federalist Movement. She is predeceased by her husband and her parents. Her father, Dr. Alexander T. Martin, served as Medical Officer in France during WWI and headed Pediatrics, Roosevelt Hospital 1938 to 1952. Her mother, Dorothy Freeman was a member of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors, and the American Institute of Chicago where she exhibited three watercolors in 1923. Survived by her brother Sandy Martin and his wife Peg, Barbara is mourned by friends, colleagues, six children, thirteen grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Interment next to Bob at Abel's Hill Cemetery, Chilmark MA. Event in her memory to be held in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please consider contributions to CTAUN or World Federalist Movement. "She is as in a field a silken tent." 1/3
